newsitem.title: INDONESIA: Indonesia non-oil revenue seen up by 14.2 pct.
newsitem.headline: Indonesia non-oil revenue seen up by 14.2 pct.

text.p: Indonesia's non-oil revenue is projected to rise by 14.2 percent to 73.18 trillion rupiah in the 1997/98 (April/March) fiscal year from an estimated 64.08 trillion rupiah in the current year, officials said.
In data made available ahead of President Suharto's 1996/97 budget speech to parliament on Monday, the government said revenue sources would include import duties, export taxes and value-added tax.
Coordinating Minister for Economy and Finance Saleh Affif told a briefing that non-oil exports were expected to rise by 14.2 percent in 1997/98.
"Non-oil exports in the coming year are expected to rise by 14.2 percent, while total exports are estimated to rise by 8.6 percent," he said.
He added that the rise in non-oil exports would be made possible by the development of export-oriented industries.
"In the past few months, we have seen the rapid growth of exports in electronic products and yarn by export-oriented factories which have just started exporting goods," he added.
The data also said income from value-added tax rose by 12.9 percent to 24.60 trillion rupiah in 1997/98 from 21.78 trillion rupiah in 1996/97.
Finance Minister Mar'ie Muhammad said total revenue from oil would account for 16.9 percent of overall budgeted income in 1997/98, compared with 18.1 percent in the 1996/97 budget.
